deliberation: Checked imperative clauses and temporal clauses. Focused on the verbs applied to abstract nouns: 'My salvation shall come' and 'My righteousness to be revealed.' Both treat abstract divine actions as if they were entities that move or are unveiled, which is standard prophetic metaphor/personification. No similes, idioms, or hyperbole detected.

instances.english_text: For soon My salvation shall come
target: YHWH’s future act of delivering His people
ground: nearness in time conceived as nearness in space
imminence / approach
time conceptualized as motion
instances.explanation: The abstract reality 'My salvation' is portrayed as an entity that can draw near and arrive, personifying salvation and using a spatial motion metaphor to express temporal imminence.

instances.english_text: And My deliverance [lit. righteousness] be revealed
vehicle: something previously hidden that is uncovered
ground: previously unseen becoming visible/public
manifestation of what was already there
knowledge/experience conceptualized as sight
instances.explanation: God’s 'righteousness'—His saving justice—is depicted as something hidden that will be 'revealed', employing a visual metaphor of unveiling to speak about public manifestation of divine action.

deliberation: Examined beatitude formula and Sabbath language; these are standard legal/cultic terms. The notable figurative element is 'keeping his hand from doing any evil,' where 'hand' stands for the person’s actions or agency. No metaphors of comparison, no personification, and no hyperbole.

instances.english_text: And holds back his hand from doing any evil
target: the person’s concrete deeds and harmful behavior
vehicle: the hand as the acting body part
ground: the hand is the usual organ of action, so it stands for what a person does
association of hand with power and deeds
part‑for‑whole representation (synecdoche)
posture: moral exhortation to total restraint from evil
instances.explanation: 'Hand' functions metonymically (and as synecdoche) for a person’s actions. To 'keep his hand from doing evil' means to refrain from any evil deeds, not only from literal actions of the hand.

deliberation: Considered whether the 'foreigner joined to YHWH' is figurative; the verb 'join' is metaphorical at a deep level but has become standard covenant language. The explicitly vivid figure is the eunuch’s self-description as 'a dry tree', clearly a metaphor of barrenness and lack of posterity.

instances.english_text: Behold, I am a withered [dry] tree
ground: lack of fruit and growth, perceived uselessness
barrenness, inability to produce offspring
life and fertility conceptualized as plant fruitfulness
posture: social and emotional complaint before God
instances.explanation: The eunuch equates himself with 'a dry tree', using plant imagery to express his sense of barrenness and lack of descendants; the tree’s dryness parallels his perceived fruitlessness.

deliberation: Most expressions are covenantal and cultic and can be taken straightforwardly. The phrase 'hold fast to My covenant' applies gripping language to an abstract agreement, which is a conventional but still figurative metaphor of loyalty as physical grasping.

instances.english_text: And who hold fast to My covenant
vehicle: firm grip that does not let go
ground: steadfast adherence likened to not letting go of something in one’s hand
stability, tenacity
commitment conceptualized as physical attachment
instances.explanation: Loyal covenant commitment is portrayed as physically 'holding fast' to an object. This conventional idiom uses a bodily grip metaphor to express steadfast faithfulness.

deliberation: Examined temple imagery ('my house', 'my walls') as largely literal for the temple precincts. The key figurative phrases are (1) 'a yad and a shem' – an idiomatic pair meaning a monumental memorial – and (2) an 'everlasting name' that 'shall not be cut off', where 'name' stands for enduring remembrance/lineage, using cutting imagery for extinction.

instances.english_text: In My House and within My walls, a monument and a name
target: the eunuchs’ honored and secure remembrance before God
vehicle: a 'hand' and a 'name' as memorial inscription or monument
monumental marker with an inscribed name
ground: permanent placement and naming signify lasting honor
publicly fixed sign standing for a remembered person
memory conceptualized as an erected structure
posture: promise of full inclusion and honor
reassuring, elevating stance toward the marginalized
instances.explanation: The idiomatic pair 'yad vashem' (literally 'a hand and a name') denotes a lasting memorial monument. Physical structures and inscriptions stand metonymically for enduring remembrance and honor in God’s temple.

instances.hebrew_text: שֵׁם עוֹלָם אֶתֵּן־לוֹ אֲשֶׁר לֹא יִכָּרֵת
instances.english_text: I will give them an everlasting name that shall not be cut off
target: the eunuchs’ perpetual remembrance and covenant place
vehicle: a 'name' that can be 'cut off' or continue
lineage or inscription subject to erasure
plant or line imagery subject to being cut
ground: to 'cut off' something is to end or annihilate it; a name not cut off endures
memory/status treated as a continuable or terminable line
continuity/termination conceptualized as cutting or preserving
posture: strong assurance against obliteration or oblivion
instances.explanation: 'Name' functions metonymically for reputation and covenant identity, and is further depicted via a cutting metaphor: unlike a line cut off, their name will not be terminated but will endure forever.

deliberation: Looked at three repeated expressions: foreigners 'joining themselves' to YHWH, 'loving the name of YHWH', and again 'holding fast My covenant'. Each uses a different figurative mapping: physical attachment for allegiance, 'name' as metonymy for God/his reputation, and grip for loyalty. No explicit similes or hyperbole.

instances.english_text: And the foreigners who are joined to the LORD
vehicle: physically attaching or clinging to someone
ground: relational loyalty likened to tight physical attachment
closeness, solidarity, dependence
relationship conceptualized as spatial nearness and bonding
posture: inclusive embrace of foreigners in covenant
instances.explanation: Foreigners’ allegiance to YHWH is portrayed as 'joining themselves' to Him, using the bodily metaphor of physical attachment to express covenantal commitment.

instances.english_text: To love the name of the LORD
target: love and reverence for YHWH Himself
vehicle: designation standing for the person and reputation
ground: a name represents the person, especially honor and reputation
addressing or loving the name equates to devotion to the bearer
person conceptualized via their name
posture: highlighting the affective dimension of worship
instances.explanation: The 'name of the LORD' stands metonymically for YHWH Himself and His reputation. To 'love His name' means to cherish and revere God, not merely the syllables of the name.

instances.english_text: And who hold fast to My covenant
target: ongoing faithful adherence to God’s covenant
vehicle: firmly holding an object in one’s grasp
ground: steadfast commitment likened to not letting go of something held
tenacity, security, refusal to release
fidelity conceptualized as a physical hold
instances.explanation: As in v.4, dedication to the covenant is depicted as physically 'holding fast' to it, using a grip metaphor to express unwavering loyalty.

deliberation: Reviewed 'My holy mountain', 'My house of prayer', and cultic terms for offerings and altar. While these phrases carry rich theological associations, in context they primarily denote the literal temple mount and its function as a prayer center. No clear metaphors, similes, personification, or idioms beyond standard cultic language were identified.

Considered whether 'gathering the dispersed of Israel' and 'I will gather still more to those already gathered' are metaphorical. Given the exile/return context, 'gather' here straightforwardly describes bringing scattered people back, either physically or communally, and is standard prophetic terminology. No distinct figurative image beyond normal usage was isolated.

The vocative summons to 'all wild beasts of the field' to come and devour functions within prophetic judgment imagery. In context with vv.10–12 (corrupt leaders as negligent watchmen), these 'beasts' represent hostile powers invited to consume the unprotected people. This is a metaphor, not literal zoological address.

instances.hebrew_text: כֹּל חַיְתוֹ שָׂדָי אֵתָיוּ לֶאֱכֹל כָּל־חַיְתוֹ בַּיָּעַר
instances.english_text: All you wild beasts, come and devour, all you beasts of the forest!
target: hostile nations or destructive forces attacking Israel
vehicle: wild beasts of the field and forest that devour prey
ground: both are dangerous, consume and destroy the vulnerable
ferocity, lack of restraint, threat to the flock
military devastation conceptualized as animal predation
posture: announcement of judgment due to failed leadership
instances.explanation: The 'wild beasts' summoned to devour symbolize invading powers or destructive agents that will ravage the unprotected people, likening national judgment to the ravages of predatory animals.

deliberation: Here the text piles images on the leaders: 'watchmen' who are 'blind', and then 'all of them dumb dogs that cannot bark, dreaming, lying down, loving to slumber.' This uses (1) sensory disability of watchmen as a metaphor for spiritual ignorance, and (2) an extended canine image (in simile form with כ־) for their failure and laziness. No hyperbole beyond the natural exaggeration of the image.

instances.english_text: His lookouts are blind, all of them; they perceive nothing
vehicle: blind watchmen who do not see
ground: a blind lookout cannot detect danger; likewise these leaders lack discernment
failure to perceive and warn
spiritual/mental incapacity conceptualized as physical blindness
instances.explanation: Leaders, portrayed as 'watchmen', are called 'blind' to depict their spiritual and moral ignorance; like blind sentries, they cannot see or understand threats to the people.

instances.hebrew_text: כֻּלָּם כְּלָבִים אִלְּמִים לֹא יוּכְלוּ לִנְבֹּחַ הֹזִים שֹׁכְבִים אֹהֲבֵי לָנוּם
instances.english_text: They are all dumb dogs that cannot bark; dreaming, lying down, loving to slumber
vehicle: mute, lazy dogs that do not bark or guard but only dream and sleep
ground: failure to sound warning and persistent laziness
uselessness, self‑indulgence, neglect of duty
leadership dereliction conceptualized as watchdogs that will not bark
posture: prophetic rhetoric aimed at shaming leaders
instances.explanation: Using a canine simile, the leaders are likened to watchdogs that neither bark nor stay alert, instead lying about in dream‑filled sleep; this vividly portrays their negligence and is rhetorically exaggerated for effect.

deliberation: This verse continues and extends the imagery from v.10. The leaders are still 'dogs', now described as greedy and never satisfied; then they are called 'shepherds' who lack understanding—a common metaphor for rulers; finally, 'they have all turned to their own way, each to his gain' uses the path metaphor for conduct/self‑interest.

instances.english_text: Moreover, the dogs are greedy; they never know satiety
vehicle: dogs with fierce appetite that never feel full
ground: unchecked desire and relentless craving
insatiability, lack of restraint
greed conceptualized as animal appetite that cannot be satisfied
instances.explanation: Keeping the dog metaphor, the leaders are portrayed as ever‑hungry animals whose craving is never satisfied, a hyperbolic image of their limitless greed.

instances.english_text: And as for the shepherds, they know not what it is to give heed
ground: shepherds are supposed to guide and care wisely; ignorant ones fail their flocks
duty of oversight and discernment
leadership conceptualized as shepherding a flock
posture: exposure of ironic contradiction between title and behavior
prophetic critique of failed pastoral care
instances.explanation: Leaders are metaphorically called 'shepherds' but are said to lack understanding, highlighting the contrast between their title and their inept performance in guiding and protecting the people.

instances.english_text: Everyone has turned their own way, every last one seeks their own advantage
target: leaders’ pursuit of self‑interest instead of public good
vehicle: movement along a road or path
ground: life choices likened to traveling along a chosen path
orientation and goal‑seeking expressed as direction of movement
moral conduct conceptualized as journeying on a road
posture: lament and accusation about universal self‑seeking
instances.explanation: The idiom of turning to 'one’s own way' uses the path metaphor for conduct, depicting each leader as choosing and walking his own path of gain rather than the way of responsible service.

deliberation: Most of the language is literal about drinking and expectation of more of the same. The key rhetorical device is the boast 'Tomorrow will be like today, great, exceedingly so', which overstates the certainty and magnitude of ongoing revelry and prosperity—a form of hyperbolic self‑assurance in the mouths of the corrupt.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהָיָה כָזֶה יוֹם מָחָר גָּדוֹל יֶתֶר מְאֹד
instances.english_text: And tomorrow will be just the same, or even much grander!
target: the leaders’ expectation of continued indulgence and prosperity
vehicle: a tomorrow that is 'great, exceedingly' like today
ground: overconfident assumption that good times will not only continue but intensify
boastful exaggeration of future well‑being
certainty conceptualized as guaranteed, ever‑greater enjoyment
posture: self‑indulgent complacency and denial of impending judgment
prophetic portrayal of folly through exaggerated speech
instances.explanation: The speakers exaggerate the certainty and degree of their future enjoyment, claiming that tomorrow will match or exceed today’s 'greatness'; this rhetorical overstatement functions as hyperbole exposing their complacent folly.
